title: R43770
content: The hidden feature of federal crimes is that helpers and offenders face the same punishment under 18 U.S.C. 2, which treats those who aid, abet, counsel, command, induce, or procure a federal crime as punishable as a principal. Aiding and abetting is more commonly prosecuted than causing a crime, requiring the defendant to associate themselves with the venture and actively participate in bringing it about. Aiding and abetting involves assisting in someone else's crime by embracing it and consciously contributing to its success. The defendant must know the offense is happening before it occurs to be convicted. The level of assistance can be minimal, as long as the accomplice does something to aid the crime. This principle continues to govern aiding and abetting law. Aiding and abetting law under §2 requires knowledge, assistance, and intent for conviction. §2(a) mandates that someone else commit a federal offense. A completed offense is necessary for aiding and abetting conviction, even if the offender is not named or convicted. Assistance must occur before or at the time of the offense. Accomplices sometimes avoid federal principles of secondary criminal liability by being less severely punished as accessories after the fact. This typically occurs when there is a significant culpability gap between the accomplice and the primary offender. Three types of accomplices include victims, customers, and subordinates, with victims being those who pay extortion, blackmail, or ransom monies. Not all victims qualify for this exception, as culpability plays a crucial role in determining eligibility. Customers who are willing participants in corrupting a public official may face conviction for bribery or as accomplices to extortion. Examples from Supreme Court cases show that customers such as drinkers, bettors, johns, and drug addicts have escaped conviction as co-conspirators. In cases like United States v. Farrar and Rewis v. United States, the Court ruled that customers of illegal establishments like speak-easies and gambling dens could not be prosecuted as aiders and abettors. This distinction also applies to federal gambling statutes, indicating that mere bettors may not be covered under the law. The federal gambling business statute, 18 U.S.C. 1955, prohibits any participation in an illegal gambling business except as a bettor. The Controlled Substances Act reinforces that drug trafficker's customers cannot be prosecuted as coconspirators. Federal law punishes traffickers severely but customers for simple possession. Subordinates may have difficulty avoiding secondary liability. In Gebardi, the Supreme Court ruled that a woman agreeing to immoral transportation couldn't be charged with conspiracy under the Mann Act. The Mann Act prohibits interstate transportation of a woman for immoral purposes. Lower courts limited this to cases where the prostitute only acquiesced to transportation. OSHA does not allow prosecution of employees of an offender. The federal gambling statute condemns those who supervise unlawful gambling enterprises. There is no consensus on how subordinates of a drug kingpin should be treated. Section 2(b) of the Mann Act applies to defendants who use intermediaries, whether knowingly or unknowingly, to commit offenses. The intermediary can be aware or unaware of their actions, and even if they are innocent, the causing individual is still liable for the underlying crime. Section 2(b) of the Mann Act imposes liability when the defendant and intermediary together commit an offense. The addition of "willfully causes" in 1951 was not clearly explained by Congress, but it is believed to address a lack of mental element in the previous version. The courts interpret "willfully" as intending the commission of conduct. An individual can be held liable under §2(b) of the Mann Act if they intentionally use someone else to commit a crime, even if they are unaware that the conduct is criminal. Federal courts may consider a withdrawal defense in aiding and abetting cases, similar to conspiracy cases, where the defendant must demonstrate affirmative action to withdraw from the scheme. The withdrawal defense in aiding and abetting cases may be more limited compared to conspiracy cases. In cases of aiding and abetting, the question of withdrawal from the crime is unsettled. Some courts have different views on whether a defendant can withdraw from aiding and abetting a crime. Proponents of a general withdrawal defense may find support in recent dicta in Rosemond, where the Supreme Court discussed the knowledge requirement for accomplices in criminal offenses. The Supreme Court clarified that an accomplice must be aware of the crime beforehand to be held accountable. There is no general civil aiding and abetting statute, so aiders and abettors may not be liable for violations of certain acts like the Anti-Terrorism Act or RICO.
